measured_by: Goal Conflict Scale (three 5-point items on curative–palliative conflict)
justification: The Method section states: “The Goal Conflict Scale (α = .73) comprised three items… ‘Curative care is detrimental to palliative care;’ … ‘Palliative care and curative care are in conflict with one another.’”

measured_by: Goal Complementarity Scale (five standardized items on helpfulness/overlap)
justification: The authors note: “The Goal Complementarity Scale (α = .68) comprised five items… ‘Curative care is helpful to palliative care’ … plus an overlapping-circles pictorial item.”

measured_by: Single item: ‘Palliative care is a strong priority’ (7-point scale)
justification: Under Materials: “Importance of palliative goals was assessed with one item: ‘Palliative care is a strong priority’ (1 = strongly disagree – 7 = strongly agree).”

measured_by: Single item: ‘Curative care is a strong priority’ (7-point scale)
justification: The questionnaire included: “Importance of curative care goals was assessed with one item: ‘Curative care is a strong priority’ (1 = strongly disagree – 7 = strongly agree).”

measured_by: Single item about fulfilling or supporting a patient’s palliative request
justification: The authors describe: “Palliative care willingness was assessed with one item: ‘If a patient requested a palliative procedure or treatment instead of a curative treatment, I would be willing to fulfill that request…’.”

measured_by: Single item about fulfilling or supporting a patient’s curative request
justification: Similarly, they state: “Curative care willingness was also assessed with a single item: ‘If a patient requested a curative procedure or treatment that I did not believe would work, I would be willing to fulfill that request…’.”

measured_by: Two items on feeling nurturing and compassionate
justification: Positive emotion was measured as: “‘How much do you currently feel nurturing?’ and ‘How much do you currently feel compassionate?’ (1 = not at all – 7 = extremely).”

measured_by: Single item about feeling less competent when unable to solve a medical problem
justification: Threat to identity was assessed with: “‘I feel less competent when I am faced with a patient who has a medical problem that I cannot solve’ (1 = strongly disagree – 7 = strongly agree).”

measured_by: Difference score between two items contrasting patients’ and self preferences for curative vs palliative care
justification: The paper explains: “Empathy gap was operationalized as the difference between two counterbalanced items: ‘The patients I see… feel it is important to seek:’ and ‘If you were a patient… you would feel it is important to seek:’ (1 = curative care – 7 = palliative care).”
